[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.1 Purpose: The Command-Line Email System (CLES) defines requirements for an email platform ensuring cross-platform compatibility, usability, and efficient message handling.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.2 Scope: CLES supports email operations, message retrieval, search functionality, and a text-based UI.

[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.1 System Interfaces: CLES integrates with SMTP for email transmission and Unix/Windows shell environments.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.2 User Interfaces: CLES provides a text-based CLI for email management.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.3 Hardware Interfaces: CLES operates on Unix and Windows-based systems with standard terminal emulation.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.4 Software Interfaces: CLES uses SMTP for outgoing mail transactions.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.5 Communications Interfa: CLES ensures secure email delivery and retrieval over standard mail protocols.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.6 Memory Constraints: CLES optimizes performance for low-memory usage environments.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.7 Operations: CLES supports sending, receiving, searching, and managing emails via command execution.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.8 Site Adaptation Requir: CLES supports execution via 'pine' command on Unix/Linux shells.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.9 Interfaces with Servic: CLES links to authentication, email storage, and system logging.

[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.4 Product Functions: CLES facilitates sending, receiving, searching, and managing emails via CLI.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.5 User Characteristics: CLES is designed for users familiar with terminal-based applications.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.6 Limitations: CLES requires shell access and SMTP configuration for email transmission.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.7 Assumptions and Dependencie: CLES relies on SMTP servers, Unix/Windows shell environments, and configured permissions.
[SUBSEC] 1.8 Definitions: Regular Expression: Pattern used for filtering emails.

[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-001: The system shall integrate with SMTP for email transmission and retrieval.
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-002: The system shall support execution via the 'pine' command in Unix shell environments.

[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-001: The system shall support sending and receiving emails, including send-only and receive-only operations (REQ-INTF-001).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-002: The system shall use a text-based interface for viewing available emails and message details.
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-003: The system shall embed a timestamp in sent messages and display it upon viewing.
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-004: The system shall enable email searches using text-based queries, allowing users to filter messages by sender, subject, and date while supporting pattern-based searches with regular expressions (REQ-DB-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-001: The system shall provide an interactive help system offering contextual guidance for commands and screens.

[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-001: The system shall process email send/receive operations within 2 seconds under normal network conditions.

[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-001: The system shall store message metadata and search index for faster retrieval.

[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-001: The system shall maintain compatibility with Unix and Windows environments, ensuring seamless execution across multiple shell types, including Bash, PowerShell, and Zsh.

[SUBSEC] 2.7 Standards Compliance.REQ-COMP-001: The system shall adhere to SMTP email transmission standards (REQ-INTF-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.8 Software System Attributes.REQ-ATTR-001: The system shall maintain low memory usage, implementing efficient caching techniques to optimize message retrieval and reduce redundant data loads for improved system performance.

[SEC] 3. Verification: Email operations, search functionality, and interface execution validated.
[SEC] 4. Supporting Information: User documentation, command syntax guide, and SMTP configuration references.
[SEC] 5. References: Email protocol best practices, command-line interface standards, and Unix, Linux system guidelines.
